sessed in another, the justice of the peace, on whose book it is erroneously assessed, shall certify the owner’s name, the quantity, description and value of the land, to the proper justice of the peace, who shall enter the same on his register and charge the tax thereon; and the justice of the peace, on whose register it was erroneously entered, shall strike the same therefrom, upon being advised of the entry thereof by the proper jus-
tice of the peace.

Sec. 19. Land lying partly in one precinct and partly in another shall be entered by the justice of the peace of the precinct in which the greater part lies; but the entry and payment of taxes in the county where any part thereof is situated, shall, for such time, be a discharge of so much of the taxes as may be so charged and paid. And when new buildings are erected of the value of one hundred dollars or more, upon that part of the land lying in the precinct in which it is not assessed, the justice of the peace, upon whose register it is entered, shall assess and add the value of such buildings as in other cases.

Sec. 20. Where land, lying partly in one precinct and partly in an-
other, is assessed in the precinct in which the greater part thereof lies, if the owner thereof shall convey that portion (or any part thereof) lying in the precinct wherein the same is not assessed, the justice of the peace of the latter precinct shall enter upon his register what is so conveyed, and certify the owner’s name, the quantity, description and valuation thereof, to the justice of the peace of the precinct wherein the whole was before assessed, who shall strike the part so conveyed from his register.

Sec. 21. When a justice of the peace shall ascertain that there is any patented land in his precinct, which has not before been entered on his register, or after having been entered, has, from any cause, been omitted for one or more years, he shall make entry
Laws of the State of Texas.thereof, and of the name of the owner, and if there be no assessment thereof, shall proceed to make such assessment to the best of his judg-
ment, by reference to the assessed value of contiguous lands similarly situated, and shall charge, on the land which he so enters, taxes at the rate imposed by law, for each year in which the land was not before so entered in such register, together with lawful interest on each year’s tax.

Sec. 22. Each justice of the peace, before making out his register, and when he takes the list of taxable personal property, shall carry with him the register of the preceding year; and the entry of lands charged to any person resident, or having an agent within his precinct, shall be shown to such person or his agent, who shall be required to state on oath whether the same be correctly entered; whether any part thereof ought to be transferred to any other person; and if so, to whom, and the nature of the evidence to authorize such transfer; also, to state whether any other land within the precinct ought to be charged to such resident or non-resident, and to describe the same, as well as to give a description of any of the lands charged to such resident or non-resident which may not be correctly entered. And the justice of the peace shall make such use of the information so obtained, as he can properly make, consistently with the other provisions of this act. Any such resident or agent failing to comply with such requisition shall be subject to a fine of fifty dollars, on indictment or information in the District Court.

Sec. 23. Each justice of the peace, before making out his register, shall assess the value of any old building omitted for one or more years, and of any building newly erected upon any land on his register, to-
gether with lawful interest on the taxes for each of the omitted years, and the value thereof shall be added to the value at which the land was before charged.

Sec. 24. No new building shall be assessed until it be so far finished as to be fit for use; but it shall then be assessed, whether entirely finished or not, at the same value as if it were finished upon the plan on which it was designed.
Sec. 25. Any building which may have been increased in value by repairs or additions thereto, to one hundred dollars or upwards, shall be assessed in the same manner as a new building.

Sec. 26. The justice of the peace, in assessing the value of any mill or other manufacturing establishment, shall ascertain the value of all machinery and fixtures attached thereto, and include the same in the amount of improvement charged to the owner thereof.

Sec. 27. The justice of the peace shall place and retain on his register the assessed value of all improved lots in any city or town
Laws of the State of Texas.within his precinct, and the value of any building thereon, as well as of all unimproved lots in any such city or town.

Sec. 38. That it shall be the duty of every person, firm, association or corporation within this State, liable to the payment of any tax, to make due return to the justice of the peace of the precinct in which they or their agent reside, when called upon by him for that purpose, in the manner hereinafter directed and described.

Sec. 29. In rendering property for the assessment of the ad valorem, tax, it is hereby made the duty of the justice of the peace invariably to administer to the person about to make such rendition the following oath, to-wit: “You do solemnly swear that the inventory now about to be rendered by you shall embrace a full and complete list of all prop-
erty owned by you, or by the person, firm, association or corporation, for which you are acting as agent, or held by you for others, within the limits of this precinct; and that you will true answers make to all ques-
tions which may be put to you concerning the same, to the best of your knowledge, information and belief, so help you God.”

Sec. 30. If the rendition embraces real estate, he will give the owner’s name, the name of the original grantee, the number under which it ap-
pears on the abstract of titled and patented lands, the number of acres improved and the number of acres unimproved, and such other descrip-
tion whereby it may be fully and easily identified. If the town lots are embraced in the rendition, they shall be described by the number of the lot and block, the name of the city or town, whether improved or un-
improved, and such other description thereof, and the improvements thereon, whereby they may be fully identified and valued.

Sec. 31. University and school lands unsold; lands or lots belonging to any county, city or town (or such towns as may have had lands granted to them,) and not held or leased out for profit; and lands on which churches, schools or colleges are erected and used for church, school or college purposes; lands occupied as cemeteries, or belonging to the insti-
tutions for the education of the deaf, dumb and blind, to the lunatic and orphan asylums, and all estate used exclusively for the safe keeping of fire engines, or hook and ladder trucks, and for the meeting of fire com-
panies, whether owned by a fire company or by a city or town, shall be ex-
empt from taxation; provided, however, any such tract of land shall not exceed ten acres; provided, all lands originally granted to persons are hereby required to be rendered for crediting on the register kept by the justice of the peace, whether exempt from taxation or not, and any sale made for want of such rendition, or for want of sufficient description whereby to identify them, whether required herein or not, is hereby
Laws of the State of Texas.declared valid and subject to redemption in like manner as unrendered property; provided, also, that nothing herein contained shall be con-
strued to exempt from taxation any lot or building partially or wholly used as a residence or for any private purpose.
Sec. 32. If the rendition be of personal property, the party making the rendition shall fully describe it, and in the following order:
1. Horses—stating the number of stock horses, the number of horses and mules of saleable age, and the number and quality of stallions, jacks and jennets.

2. Cattle—stating the number of stock cattle, and the number of saleable beeves over three years old, and the number of work oxen; and if they are other than the ordinary stock of the State, their quality in each case shall also be stated.

3. Sheep—stating the number of ewes and lambs, and if raised for slaughter, the number of wethers; but if the flock is kept exclusively for wool growing, the total number of head may be returned; but should they be of an improved or valuable breed, their quality, as well as the number and quality of bucks kept, shall be stated.

4. The number, kind and quality of all other varieties of live stock shall be stated, and the county or counties in which they range, as well as the name and address of the stock keeper or shepherd having charge of them.

5. The aggregate value of all household and kitchen furniture; the number of pleasure carriages, stage coaches, wagons, carryalls, gigs, bug-
gies and vehicles of like kind, not including those manufactured for sale. The farm property, such as agricultural implements, machinery, tools, wagons, and all other property appertaining thereto, though not enumerated herein.

6. All merchandise, or money at interest or on hand; the number, kind and quality of watches; the number and quality of clocks, piano-
fortes, harps and other musical instruments of every description; all gold and silver plate, plated ware and jewelry, not including any watches, clocks, piano-fortes, harps and other musical instruments, gold or silver plate, plated ware or jewelry, kept in any shop or manufactory for sale, and which is the subject of a license tax.

7. The aggregate amount of all solvent bonds, contracts for money or other thing, securities and liquidated claims; the amount of interest or profit arising from public bonds or certificates of indebtedness of this or any other State, or of companies incorporated by this or any other State; the yearly rent or value of ail toll bridges and ferries; the capital of all incorporated joint stock companies, and of all insurance companies which declare no dividends of profits; the
Laws of the State of Texas.amount of dividends declared by such insurance companies and savings institutions that declare dividends.

8. The capital used or invested in any manufacturing or mining busi-
ness, or invested or employed in any trade or business for which no li-
cense is required.
9. The amount of moneys, bonds, contracts or other evidences of debt, under the control of any court, receiver or commissioner.

10. The aggregate amount of the personal property, and the amount of moneys, bonds and claims of internal improvement companies, other than the equipments of a railroad company, which pays a tax on the passengers transported over the same.

11. All oilier articles of personal property not described in the enu-
meration contained in this section, nor exempted by this act.

Sec. 33. Railroad companies and other incorporated companies and associations owning property in different Counties, shall render the whole of their taxable property to the justice of the peace of the precinct in Which the principal office of such company or association is situated. Steam, sailing vessels and other sailing craft, shall render all their tax-
able property to the justice of the peace of the precinct in which the principal agency of such vessel is situated. Land shall only be ren-
dered for taxation to the justice of the peace of the precinct in which it is situated.

Sec. 34. All personal property described in this section, and to the extent herein limited, shall also be exempt from taxation; that is to say, the household and kitchen furniture used in a licensed ordinary house of entertainment, hotel or private hoarding-house, and belonging to the keeper thereof, the value whereof has been included in the license tax. All books, apparatus and furniture belonging to colleges, free schools, and incorporated academies, and used for college or School purposes; to the institutions for the education of the deaf, dumb and blind, and to the lunatic and orphan asylums. All fire engines or other implements used for the extinguishment of fires. All books, family portraits and pic-
tures, and the wearing apparel of every person, except watches and jew-
elry. All products of the soil of the present and previous years’ growth only, while in the hands of the producer. Two hundred and fifty dol-
lars’ worth of household and kitchen furniture belonging to each head of a family. All mineral productions of this State in the hands of the producer or miner. AH felled wood or timber. All plantations of oysters and fisheries. All fowls and animals of every description, ex-
cept horses, mules, asses and jennets, Cattle, sheep and hogs. All farm-
ing implements actually used for fanning purposes, except road wagons, or wagons used principally for other than farming purposes. All mechanics’ tools used on any farm, or by any person actually
Laws of the State of Texas.engaged in any trade, occupation or profession, and the products of any mechanic’s labor made in this State and kept by him for sale.
Sec. 35. The poll tax shall be assessed upon every person liable to payment thereof at the same time with the ad valorem tax.

Sec. 36. After the rendition of ad valorem and poll tax is complete, inventory and return of poll tax shall be duly entered in the inventory book, and shall be dated and signed by the person rendering the same.

Sec. 37. Each person of full age and sound mind, not a married woman, shall list the personal property, moneys, contracts and credits in his possession or under his control or care, subject to taxation, and the subjects and persons on account of which lie is chargeable with taxes. The property of a minor shall be listed by his guardian; if he has no other guardian, by his father, if living; if not, by his mother, if living; if neither be living, by the person having charge of the property; of a wife, by her husband, if of sound mind; if not, by herself; of a deceased person, idiot or lunatic, by the personal representative or committee; of a person for whom the property is held in trust, by the trustee; of a corporation whose assets are in the hands or under the control of agents, receivers, or factors, by such agent, receiver, or factor; of every company, firm, body politic or corporate, by the principal accounting officer, part-
ner or agent thereof; all moneys, bonds or other evidences of debt, under the control of any receiver or commissioner, by such receiver or commis-
sioner; and all moneys deposited in any bank, to the credit of any suit, by the clerk of the court in which such suit is pending. Personal prop-
erty not situated in the county, city or town, in which the owner or per-
son required by this act to list the same resides, shall be listed by the agent of such owner or other person in the precinct in which such prop-
erty is situated; all bonds, evidences of debt and claims, wherever the debtor may reside, and all moneys, shall be listed by the owner thereof or by the person required by this act to list the same for taxation, or by the agent of such owner or other person having the control and custody of such bonds, evidences of debt, claims, contracts and moneys.
Sec. 38. All persons who give in property, as agents for persons not resident in this State, shall be personally liable for the taxes, as well as the principal and his property.

Sec. 39. That previous to proceeding to value the property rendered, the justice of the peace shall examine the abstract of titled and patented lands; and if the lands rendered shall appear thereon, he shall affix the abstract number opposite the tract on the inventory; and shall further aid, to the best of his ability, the per-
son making the rendition, in giving a correct description thereof, so
Laws of the State of Texas.that it may be easily identified. He shall now proceed to value all the property stated in the inventory, which is situated in his precinct, at its actual specie value therein on the first day of January preceding the assessment, and for which purposes he shall ask such questions of the person rendering as may establish such value. But in case the person rendering and the justice of the peace cannot agree, each shall have the right to choose an uninterested person as an appraiser; and if the two thus chosen cannot agree as to the value, they shall call in a third ap-
praiser, and a decision of a majority shall be final. When the inventory with the established values shall be recorded in the inventory book, it shall be signed by the person rendering the same, or, in the event of his refusal, by the appraisers, or a majority of them.

Sec. 40. That in case of refusal of any person to make return of in-
ventory for the assessment of the ad valorem and poll tax, when called upon by the justice of the peace for that purpose, it is hereby made the duty of the justice of the peace to make out such inventory and schedule, according to the best information he can obtain, either by the examina-
tion of such person or his books and accounts, or by the examination of any person who may be cognizant of his business or property, or in any other manner whereby a correct return may be made. And the justice of the peace shall have the right of entry into any building or premises, other than the dwelling, to make due search for the accomplishment of this purpose, and shall have power to summons persons to give evidence in relation thereto; and for every summons so issued he shall be en-
titled to a fee of fifty cents, which shall be taxed against the prop-
erty of the delinquent; and should the books, papers, accounts or property be secreted within the dwelling of such person, it is hereby made the duty of the justice of the peace to notify the district attorney, whereby he is prevented from establishing the indebtedness of such delinquent: and it is hereby made the duty of such attorney to prosecute such delinquent for the recovery of the amount which shall be ascertained to be due, together with one hundred per centum thereon, and costs of suit. But if the justice of the peace can make out such inventory and schedule upon view of the property, or from investigation of the books and papers of such delinquent, or otherwise, he shall do so, adding the above penalty of one hundred per centum, and shall sign the inventory and record the same in the inventory book as in other cases, for which services he shall be en-
titled to twenty per cent. of all taxes and penalties collected from such delinquent, either with or without suit; and in case suit is instituted, he shall attend as witness; and in order to claim his per-
Laws of the State of Texas.centage in such cases, he shall file with the district clerk a certificate of a witness present at such refusal to render.

Sec. 41. If any person shall desire it, the justice of the peace shall furnish him, or cause to be furnished him, proper forms of such lists and valuations; and such person shall, within ten days thereafter, make out and deliver to the justice of the peace of the precinct in which he resides, statements of all property, moneys, contracts and credits, which such person is required by this act to render, and of all subjects on account of which he is chargeable with taxes. He shall annex, in the form pre-
scribed by justice of the peace, valuations of the property rendered, and shall take and subscribe an oath to be appended to such statement, as follows: “I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that to the best of my knowl-
edge, information and belief, the annexed statements contain accurate, full and complete lists of all property, moneys and credits, whether the same are in or out of the State, which I am required to list, and of all subjects on account of which I am chargeable with taxes, and that in my opinion the valuations of property listed are not below the fair cash value thereof, so help me God:” which oath may be administered by the justice of the peace or any other officer authorized by law to administer an oath; and if any person be absent from his residence at the time the justice of the peace calls (and there be no person on the premises author-
ized to act for such person,) the justice of the peace shall leave, or cause to be left for such person at his residence, with some member of his family over sixteen years of age, or, if there be no such person on the premises, shall otherwise cause to be delivered to such person, proper forms to enable him to make out the statements as aforesaid, with the form of the oath aforesaid appended thereto; and it shall be the duty of such person to make out and deliver to the justice of the peace, within ten days thereafter, such lists, with the valuations of property annexed, verified by affidavit, as are hereinbefore required. If any such per-
son, desiring the forms to be furnished him, or absent when the justice of the peace calls at his residence, shall fail to make out and deliver such lists and statements as are required herein, within the time specified in each case herein, then the justice of the peace shall proceed in the manner prescribed in section forty of this act. But any such person, desiring the forms to be furnished him as afore-
said, may be released from the obligation of valuing the property listed as aforesaid, by exhibiting the same to the justice of the peace, who shall thereupon assess the value thereof; and any such person who is absent from his residence when the justice of the peace calls, may decline to include a valuation of his property in the statements required to be delivered as aforesaid, and in such case
Laws of the State of Texas.the justice of the peace shall ascertain the value of such property; and if the justice of the peace is not satisfied with the valuation of the prop-
erty made by any such person, he may adopt what he deems to be a fair and proper valuation thereof; and in case such person shall consider himself aggrieved by such valuation, the controversy shall be decided in the manner prescribed in section thirty-nine of this act.

Sec. 42. Every railroad, canal or navigation company, shall hereafter report quarterly on the fifteenth day of March, June, September and December, in each year, to the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the gross amount received by such company for the transportation of freight and passengers over such road or canal, or part thereof, during the quarter of the year next preceding the first clay of the month in which such re-
port is made, and at the time of making such reports shall pay into the State treasury two per cent. of such gross amount received in compliance with section three of “An act to levy taxes.”1

Sec. 43. Each justice of the peace shall begin, annually, on the first day of January, and proceed without delay to ascertain all the persons and property, on that day, in his precinct, subject to taxes, and otherwise to discharge the duties prescribed by this act.

Sec. 44. The justice of the peace shall endeavor, by asking proper questions and obtaining answers thereto, to have in such lists as are re-
quired by this act, a correct and full statement of the persons, and of personal property and the value thereof in his precinct subject to taxa-
tion, which were in the possession or care of each person in such precinct on the first day of January, and of all other subjects before mentioned, on account of which any person, firm or association in his precinct was then chargeable.

Sec. 45. The answers to questions of the justice of the peace shall always be under oath; a justice of the peace failing in any case to ad-
minister such oath shall be subject to a fine of twenty-five dollars for every such failure. And should any person wilfully and knowingly swear falsely upon taking any oath required of him by this act, it shall be held perjury, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as pre-
scribed in article two hundred and ninety-two of the Penal Code.

Sec. 46. If a justice of the peace shall discover, in making up his register or property books, that any taxes have been omitted for any for-
mer year, he shall charge therein such omitted taxes, with lawful interest thereon.
1Chapter LXXXII., p. 194.

Sec. 47. Each justice of the peace shall make a book contain-
Laws of the State of Texas.ing the names of the owners of property, and other persons taxed, al-
phabetically arranged, and giving information in such form as the Comp-
troller may direct, as to all persons and subjects on which taxes may be assessed. Opposite the name of each person shall be extended the whole amount of public tax.

Sec. 48. The justice of the peace shall make a particular report, on oath, to the District Court of his county, of all his own property sub-
ject to taxes, showing the whole amount chargeable to him therefor. On his books his property shall be entered, and taxes charged to him in like manner as to any other person. For failing to perform any duty required by this section, he shall be subject to a tine of one hundred dollars.

Sec. 49. The land of any decedent shall be charged to his estate un-
til it can be properly charged to the heir, devisee or grantee. And the personal property of the decedent shall be likewise charged to his estate until the same be disposed of. While either continues charged to the estate, the personal property shall be liable for the tax on all so charged, and subject to distress or other lawful process for the recovery of the same. Any assets in the hands of the personal representatives of the de-
cedent shall be likewise liable therefor.

Sec. 50. In any case in which, in consequence of there being no jus-
tice of the peace for a former year, or from any other cause, no book was made out of the land tax, or of the tax on personal property, the justice of the peace of such precinct shall proceed to make out books for such year according to the rate of tax which then existed, as well as the books for the current year. The like proceedings shall be had with and under the books of such former year as with those of the current year, and the sums therein charged shall be collected and accounted for in like manner.

Sec. 51. The justice of the peace, after completing his land book and his book of personal property, shall make two copies thereof; at the foot of each copy he shall make and subscribe the following oath: “I, —, justice of the peace of — precinct of — county, do swear, that in making out the foregoing book, I have, to the best of my knowledge and ability, pursued the laws prescribing the duties of a justice of the peace;” and the person before whom the oath is taken shall annex thereto and subscribe the following certificate: “Sworn to before me, ——, on the — day of ——.” The oath at the foot of the copies of the land book shall contain these additional words: “and that I have faithfully discharged the duties required of me in as-
sessing improvements upon lands, and have made all corrections in said book as required by law.”

Sec. 52. The original of each book shall be retained by the
Laws of the State of Texas.justice of the peace so long as he continues in office, and then be deliv-
ered to his successor. If he fail to make the copy required by the next preceding section, he shall forfeit fifty dollars.

Sec. 53. The copies of each book sworn to as aforesaid, together with such lists, inventories and schedules, as he may have taken from indi-
viduals, shall be delivered by the justice of the peace to the clerk of the District Court of the county wherein he was elected, for examination, on or before the first day of May in each year; and he may require from such clerk a receipt or acknowledgment in writing of the delivery of tire said books, lists, etc.

Sec. 54. Such clerk shall compare the copies of the land book with the land book of the previous year, with the records of his office, where necessary, and with such transcripts, abstracts or statements from the records of other offices, as the justice of the peace shall lay before him. He shall compare the books of personal property with the lists taken by the justice of the peace from individuals, and examine the same in such other way as the records of his office and the information in his pos-
session will enable him to do.

Sec. 55. The justice of the peace shall attend at the clerk’s office and assist at such examination so far as may be required by such clerk; and the clerk shall point out to the justice of the peace such errors (if any) as may in his opinion exist in such books. Every such error shall be corrected when the clerk and justice of the peace concur as to the pro-
priety of such correction. When they differ, the matter in difference shall be submitted to the district attorney, and they shall conform to his decision. If he fail to decide the matter before the next term, it shall then be submitted to and decided by the District Court; and the books shall be made to conform to such decision.

Sec. 56. When the examination of the district clerk is completed, he shall annex to each copy of the land books a certificate to the following effect: “I——, cleric of the District Court for the county of —, do hereby certify, that I have carefully examined the foregoing land book; that I have compared it with the land book of the preceding year, with the records of my office, where necessary, and with such lists, abstracts or statements from the records of other offices as the justice of the peace laid before me, and that I find the same correct, or that such errors as were found in the book when it was delivered to me have been corrected according to law. Given under may hand this — day of —."

Sec. 57. The clerk shall annex such certificate to the copies of the property book as the result of his examination thereof will justify. And if he carelessly perform any of the duties herein required of him, his claim for the examination of the books shall be suspended
Laws of the State of Texas.until such duties are properly performed; and if he fail to perform any of the duties above required of him, he shall forfeit one hundred dollars.

Sec. 58. One copy of the land book, and one copy of the book of per-
sonal property, shall be retained by the clerk, free for the inspection of any person, and a copy of either, or any part thereof, may be had at the charge of any person desiring the same.

Sec. 59. One copy of the land book and one of the book of personal property and pol tax, shall be deliverd by the clerk to the sheriff on or before the first day of June in each year, which shall be his guide in col-
lecting the taxes therein assessed.

Sec. 60. The clerk shall, under the supervision of the District Court, and in obedience to the directions of the Comptroller, on or before the first day of June in each year, make out and forward to the Comptroller of Public Accounts one assessment roll for his county, taking as his guide the retained copies, in his possession, of the land and personal property books delivered to him by the different justices of the peace of his county.

Sec. 61. One of the assessment rolls, required by the next preceding section, shall embrace nothing but land, and which shall contain an ac-
curate and complete description of each and every parcel of land situated in the county, which can be ascertained with the aid of the county sur-
veyor, land book, county map, and such records of the surveyor’s office as may be necessary, and shall describe the same in the following man-
ner, viz:
1. Abstract number.
2. Class or nature of claim.
3. Name of original grantee.
4. Number of acres.
5. Such description of the tract or parcel of land whereby it may be easily identified; and if this is not practicable, it shall be so stated.
6. Name of owner, if known; if not known, then it shall be stated, “owner unknown.”
7. Assessed value per acre.
8. Total assessed value.
9. Amount of State tax.
10. Amount of county tax, with the rate per cent. thereof.
11. Total amount due.
12. By whom paid.

Sec. 62. The other assessment roll shall embrace all other prop-
erty, personal and real, subject to taxation, with the value thereof, and the amount of State and county tax due thereon, with the rate per cent. of county tax. It shall also embrace the amount of in-
Laws of the State of Texas.come, salary, occupation and poll tax due from each individual within the county subject to any such tax.

Sec. 63. The clerk of the District Court, at the time of forwarding the assessment rolls required herein, shall forward to the Comptroller a certificate stating that he has delivered a copy of the land and property books, and of the schedules of occupation and poll tax, to the sheriff of his county. The assessment rolls furnished by such clerk shall serve as a guide for the Comptroller to settle by with such sheriff, and shall be ad-
mitted as evidence in any proceeding for judgment against such sheriff on account of the taxes with which he is chargeable.

Sec. 64. All accounts against defaulting sheriffs, to the correctness of which the Comptroller has certified and affixed the seal of his office, shall have the same force and effect as a judgment rendered by a court of com-
petent jurisdiction.

Sec. 65. If any justice of the peace shall knowingly make a false or erroneous entry on any of his books, he shall, for every such offense, for-
feit one hundred dollars, and a like amount shall be forfeited by him for failure in performing the duties prescribed in section fifty-three of this act.

Sec. 66. If the clerk of a District Court shall fail to perform the duties required of him in sections fifty-four, fifty-six, fifty-seven, fifty-nine, sixty, sixty-one, sixty-two and sixty-three of this act, within the times prescribed therein, he shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dol-
lars nor more than two hundred and fifty dollars.

Sec. 67. If a justice of the peace, either in his land book or book of personal property, charge or extend in any case a less tax than the law requires, the amount, omitted to be so charged or extended shall be de-
ducted from his compensation.

Sec. 68. Each justice of the peace shall be entitled to the fol-
lowing fees: for making an entry and assessment, under the twenty-
first section, of any parcel of land, two dollars for every such parcel, to be paid by the owner; for making an assessment, when re-
quested by the owner of any part of the land, under the sixteenth section, two dollars, for which the parties among whom the land is divided shall be jointly and severally liable, except where the pro-
ceedings of the justice of the peace are confirmed by the County Court, in which case the party complaining shall pay the fee of the justice of the peace in addition to the costs incurred in consequence of the application to the court; for making an entry transferring lands, before charged to one person, unto another, one dollar, which shall be charged to the person to whom the transfer is made. The
Laws of the State of Texas.justices of the peace may make out bills for their fees and place them in the hands of the sheriff for collection.

Sec. 69. Every justice of the peace shall be entitled to receive, in consideration of his services under this act, a commission on me amount of taxes lawfully assessed by him on persons and property within the preceding year, as follows: on the first thousand dollars, eight per cent.; on the second thousand dollars, five per cent.; on the third thousand dol-
lars, four per cent.; on the fourth thousand dollars four per cent.; on the fifth thousand dollars, four per cent.; on the sixth thousand dollars, three per cent.; on the seventh thousand dollars, three per cent.; on the eighth thousand dollars, three per cent.; on the ninth thousand dollars, three per cent.; on the tenth thousand dollars, three per cent.; on all sums over ten thousand dollars, one per cent.; and for assessing county taxes the same rates shall be allowed.

Sec. 70. The justices of the peace shall, annually, on or before the first day of June of each year, settle their accounts with the District Court of their respective counties. The clerk of such court snail, under the seal of the court, issue to each justice of the peace, within his county, a certificate setting forth the total amount due to each for fees and for commissions for services rendered under this act, allowed by such court.

Sec. 71. The sheriff of each comity is hereby authorized, upon pre-
sentation, of such certificates by the justice of the peace of his county, to pay to each the sum indicated by the certificate held by each such justice to be due to him. And such certificate, receipted by the justice of the peace to whom the money was paid, Shall be a voucher to such sheriff for the amount so paid, in the settlement of his accounts with the Comptroller.

Sec. 72. It is hereby made the duty of the Comptroller of Public Accounts to furnish the justices of the peace, clerks of courts, and sher-
iffs, with all the blank forms and books necessary to enable them to per-
form the duties required of them by this act.
Sec. 73. Such instructions of the Comptroller of Public Accounts as may be established to carry this act into effect, shall be binding on all justices of the peace, clerks of courts and sheriffs.

Sec. 74. The compensation of justices of the peace allowed by this act, shall be denied unless he has made all the reports and performed all the duties required of him herein, within the time prescribed by law, or can show to the satisfaction of the County Court strong and sufficient reasons for delay or neglect.

Sec. 75. Where a justice of the peace makes out books for a former year, such compensation may be allowed him therefor, in ad-
dition to what he is entitled to for his services during the current
Laws of the State of Texas.year, as he would have received in a former had he then been elected and performing the duties of a justice of the peace.

Sec. 76. When one justice of the peace begins, and dies, or is re-
moved, before the services to be rendered by Mm in the term for which he was elected are fully performed, in consequence Whereof another justice of the peace is elected who completes the same, the sum to be paid for the whole services of the justices of the peace during that term shall be apportioned between the justice last elected and the former, accord-
ing to the services by them respectively performed. If, however, in con-
sequence of any failure to deliver up books and papers which the former had, or from any other cause, the latter has to proceed to take the list of taxable property, and do all that he would have had to do in case there had been no justice of the peace, then he shall recive all the com-
pensation for that term.

Sec. 77. District clerks shall receive a compensation for the services performed by them, in compliance with the requirements of this act, as follows, viz: For all transcripts of records, copies of judgments and de-
crees, etc., making out assessment rolls and reports for the Comptroller’s office, twenty cents for every hundred words, estimating each figure, ab-
breviation and character representing a word, as a word. For making the examination as required by section fifty-four of this act, five dollars for every day so employed; provided, such time shall not exceed ten days in any one year.

Sec. 78. District clerks shall annually make out their accounts and present the same to the district judge of their respective counties, and it shall be the duty of said judge, when satisfied of the correctness of such account, to issue to such clerk a certificate for the total amount due him for services rendered by him in that year under this act. Upon pre-
sentation of said certificate to the sheriff of his county, such sheriff shall pay to such clerk the amount so due him, as is provided in sections sev-
enty-two and seventy-three for justices of the peace.

Sec. 79. After the clerk shall have certified the land book, or the book of personal property, no alteration shall be made in either, by the jus-
tice of the peace, affecting the taxes of that year. But any person ag-
grieved by any entry in either book, or with any assessment of a license tax, may, within one year after the date of the clerk’s certificate, where the entry is in either of said books, and within one year from the assess-
ment of said license tax, apply for relief to the court in which the jus-
tice of the peace making such assessment gave bond and qualified.

Sec. 80. If the court be satisfied that the applicant is erroneously charged on such book, or so assessed with any taxes or licenses.
Laws of the State of Texas.it shall certify the facts upon which it grants relief, and shall order that he be exonerated from the payment of so much as is erroneously charged, if not already paid, and if paid, that it be refunded to him.

Sec. 81. Such order delivered to the sheriff shall restrain him from collecting so much as is thus erroneously charged; or if the same has already been collected, shall compel him to refund the money, if such officer has not already paid it into the treasury; and either way it shall be a sufficient voucher to entitle the sheriff to a credit for so much in his settlement with the Comptroller of Public Accounts.

Sec. 82. If, from the statement of facts or other evidence, the Comp-
troller of Public Accounts shall be of opinion that the order of the court granting redress is erroneous, he may advise a supersedeas or appeal to the District Court of the county having jurisdiction over the county in which the order was granted. Such appeal or supersedeas shall be granted as a matter of right, and shall be prosecuted by the attorney of the State for such court. The District Court, upon the facts stated, and upon such other evidence as may be produced by either party, shall affirm or reverse the order for exoneration, and shall make such order thereupon for the collection of taxes, or otherwise, as such court may consider proper. The appeal or supersedeas shall be tried in a summary manner, without pleadings in writing. Ho costs shall be awarded by the court, or paid by the State, about such appeal or supersedeas, unless the court, in its discretion, shall give judgment for costs against the justice of the peace who made the erroneous statement.

Sec. 83. It shall be the duty of every justice of the peace to furnish the district attorney for the county a statement of every violation of the revenue laws committed by any person, showing the nature and character of each such violation. And it shall be the duty of said attorney to de-
liver such statements to the foreman of the grand jury, at the next ses-
sion thereof, who shall treat it as having been given specially in charge to the grand jury. The said foreman, after the said jury is discharged, shall return such statements to the clerk of the court, to be preserved and filed by him in his office. It shall also be the duty of the District Courts, and of the attorneys for the State, specially to charge the grand juries to inquire into all violations of the revenue laws by the justices of the peace.

Sec. 84. That the words “dollars” and “cents,” as used in this act, are understood in all cases to mean the currency of the United States, except in the valuation of property, the estimation of in-
Laws of the State of Texas.comes, and the rendition of salaries, in all of which specie is intended.

Sec. 85. The sheriff in each county, in addition to the other duties required of him by law to be performed, shall annually collect all taxes assessed by the different justices of the peace within his county, in such manner and at such times as shall be hereinafter prescribed.
Sec. 86. Should the office of sheriff, from death, removal, or other cause, become vacant, the same course shall be pursued as is prescribed in section one hereof, in regard to justices of the peace.

Sec. 87. That every sheriff shall, within ten days after he has received notice of his election, give such bond, payable to the State of Texas, as shall be drawn by Comptroller of Public Accounts, by and with the ad vice of the Attorney General of the State, in a penal sum of double the probable amount of all State taxes to be collected during the year in which it is drawn, and in accordance to law, with at least three good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the Comptroller of Public Ac-
counts, and shall take and subscribe the following oath, in addition to the one prescribed by the Constitution: “I—, sheriff of the county of —, do hereby swear that I will, to the best of my ability, faith-
fully discharge the duties required of me by law, in the collection of taxes, and that I will pay over to the officers authorized by law to receive the same, all taxes collected by me, so help me Godwhich, together with said bond, shall be recorded in the office of the clerk of the District Court, at the expense of the sheriff, and shall be forwarded within ten days thereafter to the Comptroller of Public Accounts, for filing in his office.

Sec. 88. Said bond shall be deemed to extend to the faithful perform-
ance of all duties imposed on him by this act, and the instructions of the Comptroller of Public Accounts, as collector of taxes, for and during the full term for which such sheriff was elected, as well as for the collection of all sums which were uncollected by his predecessors in office, and shall also be deemed to cover the whole time from the date of its execution to the end of the term for which he was elected, and until his successor shall be duly qualified, and shall not become void on the first recovery, but suit may be maintained thereon until the whole amount thereof be recovered. The property of a sheriff shall be bound by statutory lien for three years for all moneys received by him for taxes, the date of such lien to commence from the time of his receiving the money.

Sec. 89. A sheriff may be required to give a new bond, or additional or other securities, whenever, in the opinion of the Comp-
troller, it may be deemed advisable. Should a sheriff fail to give a
Laws of the State of Texas.new bond, or additional or other securities, whenever so required, or shall appear to be a defaulter or delinquent in the performance of any important duty, or from any other cause whereby the interests of the State may be jeopardized, then and in that case he shall be removed from office by the judge of the District Court, who shall forthwith order an election to fill such vacancy for the remainder of his official term.

Sec. 90. No person who is a defaulter to the State shall be eligible to any office of profit or trust in this State until such indebtedness is re-
moved. Nor shall any sheriff enter upon the duties of his office until he shall have been duly commissioned and given bond as required herein. He shall keep his office at the county seat, which shall be stated in his official bond.

Sec. 91. The sheriff shall also give another bond, in such sum as shall be fixed by the District Court, payable to the district judge, with suf-
ficient security, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties required of him by law in the collection of county taxes.

Sec. 92. All persons offering themselves as security for a sheriff or justice of the peace, shall append to their bond, or accompany their recognizance, with an affidavit that they are actually worth the amount: for which they render themselves liable, over and above all their liabili-
ties; and such affidavit shall set forth a description of their property, or so much thereof as will be sufficient to cover the amount for which they bind themselves, and its value, and all incumbrances thereon of every nature.

Sec. 93. Should any sheriff fail or refuse to deliver up the books, papers and other archives appertaining to his office, to his successor, on application therefor, he shall be liable in a fine of not less than one hun-
dred dollars for every week he may so fail or refuse to deliver such books, papers and other archives, such amount to be recoverable on his official bond.

Sec. 94. Every sheriff shall be authorized to appoint, by instrument of writing, under his hand, as many deputies as he may deem necessary, to be by him compensated for their services; one of whom, in the event of the absence of the sheriff from the county seat, shall there remain dur-
ing such absence; and also to make any such appointment, and shall give bonds, or other securities, and accept the same from such deputy; and each deputy shall hare the like authority, in every respect, to collect taxes within that portion of the county which may have been allotted him, which the sheriff would have; but each sheriff and his sureties shall, in every respect, be responsible for every act performed or omission in-
curred by such deputy, as though the same had been performed or in-
curred by himself. Nothing herein contained shall prevent any sheriff from
Laws of the State of Texas.discharging any official duty in any portion of his deputy’s district. Every deputy so appointed shall be required, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, to take and subscribe the oath herein required to be taken by the sheriff.

Sec. 95. In case of the disability, death or removal of a sheriff, the duties herein required of him shall devolve upon his deputy or deputies, who, or either of them, shall immediately notify the Comptroller of Public Accounts of such event; and if a further continuance of the dis-
charge of their duties be not disapproved by him, he or they shall com feme to act until an election to fill such vacancy be made. But the re-
sponsibility of a sheriff and his sureties shall in no wise be affected or impaired by such disability, dearth or removal, nor shall his liability nor the liability of his securities cease until his successor in office shall have been duly elected and qualified.

Sec. 96. Any bond or security taken of a deputy by a sheriff, shall be available to the heirs or representatives of such sheriff to indemnify them from loss or damage accruing from any such deputy so succeeding temporarily to the duties of such disabled, deceased or removed sheriff.

Sec. 97. Each sheriff shall, annually, commence his collections on the first day of June, or as soon thereafter as he may receive the copies of the justices’ of the peace hoots, schedules and other data, required to be fur-
nished to him by the district clerk in section fifty-nine hereof.

Sec. 98. He, or his deputy, shall call at least once upon every person taxed within his county, or on the agent or attorney of such person, at the usual place of his or her residence, and demand the payment of the taxes charged upon his or her person and property, if the person is to be found, and if not, then a written demand, specifying the amount of taxes due, left at the usual place of residence with some member of the family over fourteen years of age, shall be a sufficient demand. He shall post, or cause to he posted, suitable notices throughout his county, stating the days on which he will he present at the county seat for the purpose of receiving taxes; and it shall be his duty to be personally present during such time so advertised; provided, it shall be no excuse to any person for not paying his taxes as the law requires, that the sheriff should fail so to advertise or fill his appointments.

Sec. 99. He shall make out, on such blanks as shall be fur-
nished him for that purpose by the Comptroller, sign and deliver to every person paying taxes, a receipt for the amount so paid; and if taxes are paid for others than those rendering, separate receipts shall be given for each The receipts shall all be numbered,
Laws of the State of Texas.and duplicates thereof, corresponding in number, name and amount with those issued, shall be kept on the margin of the receipt book, and signed by the sheriff. When the collection is completed, it shall be carefully added up and forwarded to the Comptroller of Public Accounts, who is hereby prohibited from making any settlement with any sheriff without them in view.

Sec. 100. Every sheriff or his deputy who shall exercise or be guilty of any extortion or wilful oppression, under color of this act, or shall knowingly demand other or greater sums than are authorized by this act, or other currency than that in which taxes are, by law, made payable, shall be liable to pay a sum not exceeding double the amount of damages accruing to the party injured, to be recoverable before the District Court for the use of said party, with costs of suit, and shall be dismissed from office.

Sec. 101. When the voluntary collection of the ad valorem and poll tax is complete, the sheriff, conjointly with the county surveyor, will pro-
ceed to ascertain from the land books of the justices of the peace, aided by the county map, and such other records of the county surveyor’s office as may be necessary, the lands upon which taxes have not been paid for the current year, and shall describe the same in the following manner:
1. The abstract number.
2. Class or nature of the claim.
3. Name of original grantee.
4. Number of acres unrendered.

5. Such description of the unrendered portion whereby it can be iden-
tified; and if this is not practicable, it shall be so stated.
6. Name of owner, if the same can be ascertained; if not, then it shall be stated, “owner unknown.”
7. The amount of State taxes.
8. Twenty per cent. penalty thereon.
9. The amount of county taxes.
10. Twenty per cent. penalty thereon.
11. The total amount due.

They shall then transcribe from the land book to said list, in ap-
propriate columns, and in numerical order, all the city and town lots upon which taxes are still due and unpaid. They shall then enter such personal property as may appear upon the personal property book not to have been rendered. From this general list shall be drawn as many lists as there are precincts in the county, drafting into each, as near as practicable, the property situated therein respectively, whether rendered or unrendered. Copies of each list shall be posted in at least three public places within each precinct, containing notice of the time and place of sale of said property, which
Laws of the State of Texas.time shall not be less than twenty days from the date of said notice, and shall cite the owners thereof to come forward within that time and show cause, before the District Court, why such sale shall not take place, and shall then be dated and signed by the sheriff. Upon the comple-
tion of said lists and notices, the county surveyor shall receive compen-
sation at the rate of three dollars for every day so employed—provided, such time shall not exceed twenty days in any one year—to be paid two-
thirds by the State and one-third by the county.

Sec. 102. Should any person, firm, corporation or association, fail or refuse to pay the taxes due at the time specified in said notice, and for ten days thereafter, the sheriff shall add ten per cent. additional to their taxes, and shall notify them through the postoffice, taking the post mas-
ter’s receipt for the notices mailed, of the taxes and penalty owing; and shall further notify such delinquent, that if payment thereof be not made within ten days from, the mailing of such notice, that sufficient of the personal goods, chattels or effects of such delinquent, will be taken into possession by the sheriff, or his deputy, for the satisfaction of the taxes and penalties and costs accruing. And it is hereby made the duty of the sheriff, upon the expiration of the time stated in said notice, to proceed in conformity therewith by taking into possession any of the personal effects, of whatever character, of such delinquent, that he can find, leaving a description, of the goods, chattels or effects distrained upon, with some person over fourteen years of age, at the place where the distraint was made, in which, description the time and place of sale shall be stated, which time shall not be less than ten days from the date of such service. At the expiration of such time, he shall sell the same at public outcry, to the highest bidder; provided, that such sale shall not take place if payment be made of the taxes and penalties, together with cost of removing and taking care of said goods, chattels and effects, and one dollar for making such distraint within the time speci-
fied. If the goods, chattels and effects first seized, shall be insufficient to satisfy said taxes, penalties and costs, then the sheriff shall make an additional levy and sale, and shall so continue until said taxes, penalties and costs are satisfied, or until the goods, chattels and effects of such de-
linquent are exhausted.

Sec. 103. In cases where the personal property distrained is not di-
visible, the sheriff shall sell the whole to the highest bidder, and the surplus, if any, after paying the taxes, penalties and costs, shall be paid to the former owner of such property; and if the former owner cannot be found, it shall be paid into the State treasury to his credit, and shall be refunded upon satisfactory proof to the Comptroller of Public Ac-
counts.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 104. If, for want of bidders, any personal property cannot be sold, the same shall be bid in by the sheriff for the State, and a certifi-
cate of purchase issued therefor; and such property, so bid in, may be sold at any time thereafter as the Comptroller of Public Accounts may direct, and no property so sold shall be subject to redemption. It is intended by this provision to authorize the sheriff to seize and sell any personal property within his county belonging to a delinquent, though the same be exempt from execution in other cases.

Sec. 105. When land is sold for taxes, as provided by law, upon the payment of the amount bid by the purchaser, the sheriff shall issue an order of survey therefor, to the county surveyor, who shall survey the same, or cause it to be done, in the manner directed, and at the ex-
pense of the purchaser, and return the field notes thereof, duly certified to by him, to the sheriff, who, upon payment of the charges for survey-
ing, and a fee of three dollars, shall issue to the purchaser a deed there-
for, which, when recorded, shall confer absolute and complete title, and have all the force and effect of a deed in fee simple, and shall give the purchaser immediate and full possession. Such deed shall be regarded as prima facie evidence that all the requirements of this act have been duly complied with. Nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to authorize the sale of a homestead for the payment of any tax ex-
cept such taxes as may be assessed upon the value of such homestead.

Sec. 106. If, from any cause, the sale of property seized for taxes shall not take place at the time first appointed, the sheriff shall appoint some other time, give the like notice, and proceed to sell such property in the manner prescribed in the first instance in this act.

Sec. 107. When any sheriff can find no property of a delinquent on which to levy any tax execution in his hands, it shall be his duty to issue summons of garnishment against any person whom he may believe is indebted to the delinquent, or has in his possession any property, money or effects belonging to him; and such summons shall be served at least fifteen days before the sitting of the court to which the same is made returnable, and returned to the District Court of the county for which he is sheriff.

Sec. 108. Said sheriff shall enter on said execution the names of the person or persons garnisheed, and return the same to the District Court; and all subsequent proceedings shall be the same as is provided by law in relation to garnishments in other cases where judgment has been ob-
tained or execution issued.

Sec. 109. It shall be the duty of the Comptroller, or the sheriff, as the case may be, to receive the tax on a part of any lot,
Laws of the State of Texas.piece or parcel of land charged with taxes; provided, that the person paying such taxes, shall furnish the sheriff, or Comptroller, as the case may be, with a particular specification of such part; or if the part so paid upon be an undivided share, shall state to the sheriff, or Comp-
troller, as the case may be, who the owner of such share is, that it may be excepted in case of sale for tax of the remainder.

Sec. 110. If any person, after the return of any tax is made by him and is still due and unpaid, or any person subject to an occupation tax which is still due and unpaid, shall attempt to remove any property out of the county where the same was rendered, or is liable to tax, without the prepayment of all taxes due by such person, it is hereby made the duty of the sheriff forthwith to distrain upon a sufficiency thereof as will satisfy the taxes, penalties and cost which may be due, and sell the same in the manner heretofore directed in other cases.

Sec. 111. A person not residing in the county in which his land may lie, may, on or before the first day of April in any year, pay into the State treasury, in advance, the taxes assessed on such land for that year, upon a certificate of the Comptroller of Public Accounts, for which cer-
tificate a fee of one dollar shall be paid to that officer. A list of such payments shall be transmitted by said Comptroller, immediately after the first day of April, to the sheriffs of the counties wherein such lands may be situated, who shall make the proper entry thereof, and be al-
lowed a credit therefor in their settlement with the Comptroller.

Sec. 112. No deed of trust, or mortgage upon goods or chattels, shall prevent the same from being distrained and sold for taxes assessed against the grantor of such deed, while such goods or chattels remain in such grantor’s possession; nor shall any such deed prevent the goods and chat-
tels conveyed from being distrained and sold for taxes assessed thereon, no matter in whose possession they may be found.

Sec. 113. The sheriff shall, after the close of the annual sales in his county, make out a list of those persons who have failed to pay their taxes, and who are not possessed of any property upon which to levy to secure their payment; and upon said list being sworn to before a justice of the peace or notary public, that he has made due search and has been unable to find any property upon which to levy, the County Court shall allow him credit for the amount of county taxes due thereon, and shall certify that fact upon said list; and it shall be the duty of the Comptroller of Public Accounts, upon presentation of such list so certified to, to allow him credit for the amount of State taxes due thereon, in his annual set-
tlement of accounts.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 114. As soon as the insolvent list has been allowed, and not later than the first day of November in every year, the Sheriff shall pro-
ceed to the seat of government to settle his accounts for that year, which accounts shall be made out in such form and manner as shall hereafter be prescribed in instructions from the Comptroller of Public Accounts.

Sec. 115. It shall be the duty of every sheriff to forward to the Comp-
troller, every three months, a statement in writing of all moneys collect-
ed by him for State taxes, giving the names of the persons from whom such taxes were received, and on account of what tax. He shall also forward, every three months, to the county treasurer of his county, a similar return of all moneys received by him for county taxes; and he shall annually, on or before the first day of December, pay over to the State treasury, upon warrant of the Comptroller, all moneys collected by him for State taxes. He shall also pay over annually, on or before the first day of December, to the county treasurer, all moneys collected by him for county taxes. He shall at all times pay any drafts drawn upon him by the State Comptroller of Public Accounts, whenever he shall have funds of the State in his hands.

Sec. 116. No title to land shall be given until is is affirmatively proven that the State taxes, with fifty per cent. annual interest thereto,, have been paid; and if any clerk of a court shall record any deed to land, unless accompanied by positive evidence, to be filed with the deed, that all State taxes up to the date of the deed, with the interest thereon, have been paid, he shall for every such offense be find in the sum of not less than two hundred and fifty dollars nor more than five hundred dollars, and shall be imprisoned for not less than one nor more than five years in State penitentiary; and any deed which may be executed and recorded in violation of the provisions of this section shall be null and void.

Sec. 117. In case of any default or malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office, under this act, by any sheriff or any of his deputies, such sheriff and his sureties shall be liable to be sued on their bond or bonds in the District Court of Travis county. The Comptroller shall immediately publish notice in some newspaper published in the city of Austin, setting forth that he will, within three months there-
after, file in the office of the District Court of Travis county, with the clerk thereof, an accurate and certified account of the amount with which such sheriff is chargeable; and thereupon such clerk shall enter up a judgment against such sheriff for the amount wherewith he is so chargeable, with lawful interest thereon from the date of such default until the date of payment, and in addition thereto ten per cent. penalty, unless the Comptroller shall recommend a redue-
Laws of the State of Texas.tion thereof, which judgment shall have the same validity and be subject in all respects to the like proceedings thereupon as if it had been rendered by the court.

Sec. 118. Any person, firm or association, wishing to engage in any of the vocations or callings enumerated in “An act to levy taxes,” upon which a tax is imposed, shall, before engaging therein, make application to the sheriff: of the county in which he or they intend pursuing such vocation or calling, and make payment of all faxes imposed by law upon such occupation; and the receipt therefor from such sheriff shall entitle such persons, on application to the clerk of the County Court, to a li-
cense to pursue such vocation or calling during such period, authorized by law, as may be covered by the amount of said receipt; provided, that when a license to pursue any vocation or calling is desired for a shorter period than one year, and not less than four months, the sheriff may receive the amount required in proportion to the time for which such license is desired.

Sec. 119. The sheriff, previous to issuing any receipt, shall administer to the applicant the following oath: “You do solemnly swear that you are not liable to the payment of any other tax on occupations, as im-
posed by ‘An act to levy taxes,’ than that for which application is now made, so help you God.”

Sec. 120. When any person shall fail or refuse to comply with the requirements of the two next preceding sections, before engaging in any occupation or calling on which such tax is imposed, or within ten days after the expiration of a license, it shall be the duty of the sheriff forth-
with to levy on any property of such person to be found within the county, sufficient to pay the amount of such tax for one year, with twenty-five per cent. penalty additional, and all costs, and sell the same at public auction, to the highest bidder, for cash, after advertising such sale for ten days, by putting up a notice thereof at the Court-house door, and a printed notice insetted in some newspaper published at the County seat, if there is one published.

Sec. 121. And any person so failing or refusing to pay such tax shall be liable to a fine in a sum of not less than fifty nor more than five hun-
dred dollars.

Sec. 122. Every sheriff shall receive as compensation for the duties performed by him under this act, as follows: for making out lists of unrendered real estate and personal property as required in section one hundred and six hereof, he shall receive twenty cents for every hundred words contained in such lists; for repairing to the capital to settle his accounts with the State Comptroller, mileage at the rate of twenty cents per mile going and returning; for collect-
ing all taxes as required by this act, on the first thousand dollars so collected, eight per cent.; on the second thousand dollars, five per
Laws of the State of Texas.cent.; on the third, fourth and fifth thousand dollars, four per cent.; on the sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth and tenth thousand dollars, three per cent.; on all over ten thousand dollars, one per cent.
Sec. 123. It shall be the duty of the Comptroller of Public Accounts to make a minute and complete index hereof, before having the same printed or distributed.

Sec. 124. That all acts heretofore passed for the assessment and col-
lection of taxes, and all laws amendatory thereof that are in conflict with this act, be and the same are hereby repealed.

Sec. 125. That the sum of three thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, is hereby appropriated, out of any money in the treasury not otherwise appropriated, for the purchase of blanks and con-
tingencies necessary to carry this act into effect.
Sec. 126. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXV.

opener.salute:
An Act to provide for the sale of the Houston Tap and Brazoria Rail-
way.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That in order to secure, as far as practicable, the indebtedness of the company owning the above named railroad, to the State of Texas, and save that portion of the common school fund from entire loss, the Gov-
ernor of the State is hereby authorized and required to sell said railway, together with all the rights and property of the Houston Tap and Brazoria Railway Company, at the time, upon the terms and in the mode provided in the following sections of this act.

Sec. 2. In view of the depreciated and constantly decreasing Value of said property, the sale shall take place within ninety days from and after the final passage of this act. Due notice for said sale shall be given by the Governor for at least thirty days previous to the day of sale, of the time, terms and conditions of such sale, by publication in a news-
paper published in the city of New York, and a newspaper published in the city of New Orleans, and in three newspapers published in the State of Texas.

Sec. 3. Said sale shall be made at the front of the capitol in the city of Austin, and shall be conducted by the Governor, or by
Laws of the State of Texas.some one appointed by him for that purpose. It shall be to the highest and best, bidder for cash; and the Governor is authorized and required to execute and deliver to such purchaser a deed of conveyance to the property so sold, whenever such purchaser shall have entered into good and sufficient bond, payable to the Governor of the State, in the sum of ($50,000) fifty thousand dollars, conditioned that such purchaser will keep said railway in running order, and will not remove, or cause to be removed, any of the iron from the track of said railway, or any of the rolling stock therefrom; provided, that the Governor of the State shall be authorized to purchase said railway, if, in his discretion, he may deem [it] necessary to protect the interests of the State; provided further, that should said railway, when offered for sale to the highest bidder, not bring the sum of ($100,000) one hundred thousand dollars Coin, the Governor is hereby authorized to purchase the same for the State.

Sec. 4. The proceeds of the sale, after paying all the necessary ex-
penses thereof, shall be deposited in the treasury of the State, with the common school fund and as a part thereof.
Sec. 5. All laws and parts of laws conflicting with this act are hereby repealed; and this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.
